title: Moderation Matters: Measuring Conversational Moderation Impact in English as a Second Language Group Discussion
author: Rena Gao (The University of Melbourne), Ming-Bin Chen (The University of Melbourne), Lea Frermann (The University of Melbourne), Jey Han Lau (The University of Melbourne)
relevance_why: The study demonstrates an automated approach to assess dialogue quality, which could be applied to enhance conversational models in audio and voice interactions.
background: This paper examines the impact of moderators in group discussions among English as a Second Language speakers to enhance engagement and dialogue quality.
contribution: This paper introduces a dataset and a framework to evaluate moderation strategies, achieving improved dialogue quality in ESL discussions.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior methods did not effectively assess multi-party ESL dialogues or measure moderation impact quantitatively.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs automated assessment tools combined with specific moderation strategies tailored for ESL contexts to evaluate and enhance discussion quality.

key_innovation: The research uniquely integrates automatic dialogue quality evaluation methods with a framework designed specifically for ESL group moderation, allowing for data-driven insights.
real_world_impact: The findings can be applied to enhance educational practices and conversational AI systems, improving engagement for ESL speakers in both academic and practical settings.
limitations: The dataset is small, limited to a specific demographic, and influenced by the moderation styles of only two moderators.

new_terms.ESL: **English as a Second Language** refers to the study or use of English by non-native speakers.
new_terms.moderation strategies: **Moderation strategies** are techniques employed by moderators to facilitate and enhance group discussions.

open_sourcing: Code and data are available at https://github.com/RenaGao/L2Moderator
